column4: for some very strange reason /sbin/killall5 is not executable program but some random binary chunk of data. no idea why
the program is installed by sysvinit-utils. you may try to reinstall this package. but if you haven't played with your file system, maybe someone else did...
you may try to track the changes to your files with something like aide but this is very annoying with lots of updated packages
chkrootkit did not find anything suspicios..
chkrootkit cannot give the ultimate answer if your fs has been tampered. it won't find custom rootkits
it's best to start with fresh install tracked by aide. its a lot of work but if you need to be sure this is the safest way
this may be the ultimative solution. i still would like to know if this is the case
i don't understand your last sentence: what do you want to know?
if you want to know if your install have been tampered with and you have spare partition and your install is pretty standard
you can make a similar install on the spare partition and binary compare the files
a fresh install with an ids would be the ultimate solution but i still would like to know if this an error caused by an update or something else or the system got infected by some backdoor/rootkit
it will take a lot of time and work but you'll see if other files have been manipultated also (or if they are some unexpected new files)
is there any documentation to this file-to-file compare and how do that? what should i search for?
diff -r /mnt/oldinstall /mnt/newinstall (from lifecd preferrable in order not to consider /proc)
you may want to use "-q" for diff also. take a look at the man page
i found some hidden directories in /dev.  /dev/.static (directory)  /dev/.udev (directory)  /dev/.initramfs (directory)  /etc/.java (directory)
/dev/.static is ok. not sure for the others
i have them here too
without /dev/.java
but a binary compare is better because rootkits try to hide in well known locations (preferrably directories which change a lot). one of the fascinating ideas was directory named "..."
apt-get --reinstall install sysvinit did it but ill have an eye on it and probably will check it from a livecd, with a fresh isntall. thank you for you help, i apreciated it.
you're welcome
